Q5: What, if anything, do you feel was natural about your interaction with VAL?
Q6: What, if anything, do you feel was unnatural about your interaction with VAL?
Q7: Do you have any other comments about your experience with VAL?

{"ImportId":"Create New Field or Choose From Dropdown..."}

Q5: VAL is correctly displaying the steps I told it in the exact order I provided.
Q6: Though the steps are in the correct order and the number of displayed steps are also correct, VAL missed a few steps when performing the actions.
Q7: VAL is interesting to interact with. The interface is clear and easy to understand. I think my experience would be better if I can revisit the game instructions during the interaction. I did not know that I can pick up and put down things at the same place. Besides, I also find it a bit confusing that VAL cannot use the empty space to put down things.

Q5: I liked that VAL used natural language that felt fluent and conversational, it felt like a real person could have been asking those clarifying questions
Q6: On the "teach" command, it did not feel natural that VAL said "these are the individual steps of your command, right?" because it felt like it was not responding to my statement that I wanted to teach them and instead were clarifying that I was telling them to do something instead. This was confusing and I did not understand that I was meant to respond "yes" to that question.
Q7: When giving VAL 6 steps, their question with the task description only showed 5 responses the first time which was incorrect, but when I added the 6th command it then showed me the full 7 commands which was confusing. I also do not know how to remove or change steps individually, so I think I would have to rewrite it out (but it crashed because I copy and pasted them). I enjoyed this experience, but I found it hard to understand some things that VAL was asking.

Q5: I think being able to use natural language to give VAL instruction is natural.
Q6: At first, I am not sure about VAL's knowledge and mental model of the world. I don't know the level of details its action has. For example, I didn't know if moveTo means go to the tile coordinates, or the objects in the world. After I learned that it goes to the object, I don't know if VAL would automatically face the objects. I had to command it around and observe its behavior to figure those out. I tried to directly ask related questions, but VAL 'thought' I was giving it commands. Overall, not knowing the other conversation partner's knowledge, and action detail level, and not able to clarify with language feel unnatural.

Q5: Being able to type the message was pretty natural
Q6: It needed very granular steps to perform individual actions, which would be implicit when speaking to people. If I said to bring the onion soup to the drop off area, it's implied to plate it and take it to the drop off area, I just needed to explain each step
Q7: The system did crash both times I tried using it. It occurred both times when it asked me what was the object of the high level task (such as make()). If I specified an object, it would crash, but if I didn't specify an object it would not crash

Q6: teaching val a new command. Any time I typed something like "i want to teach you how to x", it asked me if i wanted to perform the action of "i want to teach you how to x". The only way I found that I could teach it how to do things was to tell it to do something, and then clarify that i wanted to teach it how to do a new thing.

Q5: While I understood the initial task with two actions, it was difficult to merge actions to create new actions (for instance, put the onion in the pot). Further, I tried to go to the pot and type "pressSpace()" and often it did not cook the onion, and I feel like some form of hints may help progress these conversations.
Q6: Unlike LLMs such as GPT where you may not know all the possibilities of combinations, having only 2 actions felt a little limiting. Further, it was confusing to use the same action (pressSpace) for both pickup, and cooking the onion soup. For instance, i tried to add parameters to pressSpace thinking that might mimic the "holding space bar" experience from when I was using the keyboard. The reply back was always quite generic (i.e., I did not understand the action)
Q7: The experience crashed once when I was trying to teach VAL how to compound actions such as "put the onion into the put" which aggregates many actions.

Q5: I thought the way it listed the perceived steps was natural. Although there was some weirdness with hallucinating a step and duplicating a step.
Q6: See above comment about hallucination and duplication. Also, I thought the phrasing was a bit strange when adding a new command. I tried saying "I want to teach you to make soup" and it said it didn't understand. Then when I said "make soup" it says it doesn't have that command and says there is one step "make soup" asking me to verify. This way to decomposing the new task into a single step threw me off some.
Q7: I was impressed that VAL was able to learn to make soup with a single command. The way it structured some of its commands in terms of the arguments that were passed to them seemed a bit strange to me. Additionally, adding some method for editing steps of the final command, beyond pressing undo repeatedly would be helpful.

Q5: VAL rephrased my instructions in a new way, verifying understanding. It's clarifying questions made it easy to see when I made a mistake in my instructions or when they were confusing.
Q6: After asking VAL to do the same task with the same phrase multiple times, the questions confirming the commands and arguments were tedious.
Q7: A wait command would be nice!

Q5: It's comprehension of my sentences which were fairly casual in tone
I could use very natural phrases and VAL understood me
Q6: VAL's clarification/confirmation questions felt very repetitive. Although I found them helpful to check that VAL parsed my instructions correctly, it also felt tedious to answer them all the time.
Q7: The experience was great. I assume that the learned instructions can be used in future tasks (although we only completed one in this study), which would be very convenient and time efficient.

Q5: The actual interaction (i.e., language, phrasing) felt natural. Including phrases like "..., right?" made the interaction feel casual and less intimidating.
Q6: It was difficult to undo or go back. I first told VAL an incorrect sequence (I forgot a double space bar to actually cook the soup), and it was not easy to re-teach VAL from scratch. I tried things like repeat step 4 twice and please forget that knowledge (to completely restart from scratch), but VAL didn't understand those commands, so the interaction felt a bit rigid in what VAL was capable of understanding.
Q7: It's a fun interaction, definitely! I enjoyed working with VAL. I did run into an issue where I said something straightforward and VAL wasn't able to understand (press space twice, or pressSpace() then pressSpace() again). VAL wasn't updating the sequence even when I tried to overwrite it, which made me feel like I was working against some strong short-term memory (i.e., that the information stored in VAL's memory was being weighted more heavily than new inputs)
